Cycled through all the batteries and on one occasion I got the camera on long enough to do a factory reset.  Thought that solved the problem because afterward the camera screen turned on but after just a few minutes, it went black again.  Tried all the normal tricks - swapped batteries; left the battery out for 10-mins, swapped simcards, cycled on/off my Iphone and finally deleted and reinstalled the DJI app.  Finally, got online and after 30-mins with DJI online support (total waste of time as the tech couldn't understand why I couldn't access the camera menu, even after I repeatedly told him the screen was black) he sent me a link to basically send the camera in for repair.  I'm not sure if it'll be under warranty or not.  My bet is it won't be and the repair will be more than I paid for the unit.  I have always inspected any electronics as soon as I get them and the one time I didn't, I get burned.

I bought the Osmo Action 4 to replace my GoPro Hero 11, and it completely blew my mind. It outperforms the GoPro in every way, including low light performance.

I love how easy it is to attach the mount to the camera, and the front touchscreen is a great bonus. I primarily use it for my travel videos‚Äîwhether it's mounted in my car or in rainy conditions, I can rely on it without worrying about weatherproofing, unlike my usual camera.

I‚Äôm definitely looking forward to getting another one!

Nice stabilization; battery length is adequate (I bought the combo with 2 additional batteries); the standard setting is just too wide for my purposes; I prefer the narrow mode (which is still a wide angle).  The design and weight makes this a stable platform; it doesn't feel cheap.  It should have come with a protective case or at least a lens protector, which is why I'm not giving it 5 stars.  The video is clear.

The camera came missing essential screws to actually lock in place magnetic rod and other attachments. The protective cover lens came cracked. The insides were also corroded with a white powder. When I would put battery inside to turn camera on in would begin to overheat but wouldn‚Äôt turn on.

Beautiful image quality, with unbelievable motion stabilization- there will never be a need for tripods with functions like this!

DJI has pulled my recommendation away from GoPro until something really big changes in terms of value for the money.

The value of the entire DJI ecosystem is what makes this little guy the MVP on an indie video producers' team.

Functionality Checklist:
Super lightweight, with no need for waterproof housing.
Shock case makes vertical videos easy.
Pairing with wireless mics? Easy.
Compatibility with other accessories? Mega easy.
Setting advanced color modes & profiles? Yup, also a piece of cake.
Image stabilization? So many modes, you could attach it to the top of a roomba, and it would look like a $1M dolly shot- still in 4k at 120 fps.
Slow motion for days.
Easy log profiles for flat color output.
Decent in-camera audio for the casual vlog or family production on social media.

The one limitation I have found is letting the camera dunk a little too deeply in saltwater for a little too long.

Clearly I'm not the only person saying this.

But man, what an exciting time to be making content!

As someone who‚Äôs used multiple GoPros over the years, I decided to give the DJI Osmo Action 4 a shot for mountain biking and kayak fishing footage‚Äîand it far exceeded expectations.

The 1/1.3-inch sensor delivers exceptional low-light performance, and the image clarity and color reproduction are on par with (if not better than) more expensive competitors. RockSteady 3.0+ stabilization is incredibly smooth, even on rough trails or choppy water, and the horizon leveling is a huge plus.

Battery life is impressive, especially in extended shooting modes, and the magnetic quick-release system is extremely convenient when switching mounts. The DJI Mimo app syncs quickly, and the LightCut app streamlines editing with smart templates that actually look good.

At $249, this is hands-down the best value in action cams right now. If DJI improves the touchscreen responsiveness just a bit, this would be a near-perfect setup. Easily a 6-star product.

One of the most frustrating aspects is its inability to function out of the box. You absolutely cannot use this camera until you go through the device registration process. This might seem like a minor inconvenience, but it's a significant barrier for anyone wanting to quickly capture a moment. Imagine being on location, ready for that perfect shot, only to be sidelined by a mandatory and often fiddly setup process with the DJI Mimo app.

This forced registration also raises privacy concerns. Users are required to connect their device to DJI's servers and provide personal data, potentially including:

Account information

Contact information

Location data

Device usage information

This level of data collection, simply to activate a camera, feels invasive and unnecessary. The issue is further compounded for Android users, who are often required to download the DJI Mimo app via a QR code provided on the camera, which leads to installing an APK file from an unknown source. This process forces users to bypass built-in Android security protections designed to prevent the installation of potentially harmful software.

By contrast, GoPro cameras do not require registration to be used. While GoPro may collect data through app usage or optional account creation, users can start capturing footage immediately without this initial hurdle. This difference highlights a significant divergence in approach to user privacy.

[[VIDEOID:b861e05e0cef2656f742a2fee1628a84]] The DJI Action 5 Pro camera has the same form factor as the Action 3 and Action 4 camera, so it will fit in all of the same accessories. The Essentials combo pack assumes you already have some action camera mounts, and only includes the camera.

I turned the screen on and it recorded 1080p continuously for 3 hours and 45 minutes, so I believe their 4+ hour battery life (if you let the screen auto turn off).

When you plug it into a computer, you can transfer files as if it is a hard drive, or use it as a PC webcam, or just charge the battery via the USB-C port. It has 64GB of native storage, which you can add to with a user supplied microSD card.

It is designed to be natively waterproof down to 20 meters as long as the ports are latched closed. I've only tested it under a few feet of water, but it worked great sticking it under my dock.

The subject tracking and stabilization work great. Shooting an HD vertical video while holding the camera horizontally gave a large amount of left/right play for the subject tacking to really work in. If you shoot a horizontal video while holding the camera horizontally it tracks/stabilizes within a smaller window but doesn't have as much space around the "edges" to work with.

The touch screen interface on the rear is relatively easy to use (you have to play around a bit to figure out which of the 4 "swipe directions" goes to what configuration menu, but after you figure things out it's not difficult to navigate through the various menus to select different modes. I especially appreciate the timelapse mode for documenting the "big pict

ure" of projects.

In short, it's a solid action camera with all the features you might want or need, great image quality, good sound quality in a robust package.
